title: Mobile Salt Section Drilling
description: Decision-making when drilling through mobile salt/evaporite sections with associated stuck pipe and hole stability challenges

scenario.context: You are drilling the 16" hole section through a known evaporite/salt interval. Current depth is {{currentDepth}} m. The well plan calls for KCl polymer mud at {{mudWeight}} sg transitioning to OBM at the base of salt.

questions.question: Torque has increased by 15% over the last 3 stands and you're seeing intermittent overpull on connections. What are the likely causes and what's your immediate response?
keyPoints: Cutting beds from inadequate hole cleaning
Immediate: Increase circulation, work pipe, consider wiper trip
questions.correctResponse: Mobile salt is likely closing in on the drillstring. Immediate response: increase circulation rate to maximum, work pipe continuously, pump high-viscosity sweeps. If overpull exceeds {{overpullLimit}} klbs, initiate wiper trip. Consider increasing mud weight or converting to OBM earlier than planned if condition persists.
incorrectIndicators: Pull out of hole without circulation

questions.question: You've been circulating for 2 hours trying to work through a tight spot at {{tightSpotDepth}} m. Overpull is now 80 klbs despite jarring. What are your options and decision criteria?
keyPoints: Spotting fresh water pill to dissolve salt
Decision point for fishing vs sidetrack
Time vs cost vs risk assessment
questions.correctResponse: Options: 1) Spot fresh water pill (50-100 bbls) to dissolve salt around pipe - allow 30-60 min soak time, 2) Continue jarring with defined jar count limit, 3) If fresh water ineffective, consider acid wash, 4) Set time limit (typically 8-12 hours) before declaring stuck and initiating fishing/sidetrack decision. Fresh water pill is first choice for salt-induced sticking.

questions.question: You're approaching the base of salt at {{saltBaseDepth}} m and need to convert from KCl polymer to OBM. Walk me through the conversion process and critical monitoring points.
questions.correctResponse: Conversion process: 1) Condition hole - circulate clean, pump sweeps, 2) Pump spacer train (typically base oil spacer + surfactant), 3) Displace with OBM from bottom up, 4) Monitor returns for contamination, 5) Check OBM properties after full displacement. Critical points: Ensure no WBM contamination (affects OBM stability), verify rheology before continuing, confirm environmental permits for OBM discharge.

discussionPoints: Why is salt creep worse at higher temperatures and depths?
What are the indicators that salt is mobile vs stable?
How does mud weight affect salt creep rate?
When should you pre-emptively convert to OBM vs wait for problems?
